title: B2 Grammar - General Review 1
subject: english
description: Upper-intermediate review covering Narrative Tenses, Future Forms, Modals of Deduction, and Conditionals.

questions.text: By the time we arrived at the station, the train _____ left.
questions.explanation: Past Perfect ('had left') is used for an action that happened before another past action (arriving).

questions.text: I _____ working on this project for three hours when you called.
questions.explanation: Past Perfect Continuous emphasizes the duration of an activity up to a point in the past.

questions.text: This time next week, I _____ on a beach in Bali.
questions.explanation: Future Continuous ('will be lying') describes an action in progress at a specific future time.

questions.text: You _____ seen him yesterday; he is currently in New York.
questions.explanation: Modals of deduction: 'can't have' expresses a strong belief that something was impossible in the past.

questions.text: If I _____ you, I would accept the offer immediately.
questions.explanation: Second Conditional: 'If I were you' is the standard form for giving advice in hypothetical situations.

questions.text: I wish I _____ harder for the exam. I didn't do very well.
questions.explanation: To express regret about the past using 'wish', we use the Past Perfect tense.

questions.text: The phone rang while I _____ dinner.
questions.explanation: Past Continuous ('was cooking') is used for a longer background action interrupted by a shorter action.

questions.text: We won't go to the park _____ the weather improves.
questions.explanation: 'Unless' means 'if not' or 'except if'.

questions.text: He _____ to be one of the best doctors in the city.
questions.explanation: Passive reporting structure: 'He is said to be...' is used to report general opinion.

questions.text: I'll send you the report as soon as I _____ it.
questions.explanation: In future time clauses (after as soon as), we use Present Simple or Present Perfect, not 'will'.

questions.text: She admitted _____ the mistake.
questions.explanation: The verb 'admit' is followed by the gerund (-ing form).

questions.text: You'd better _____ a coat; it's freezing outside.
questions.explanation: 'Had better' is followed by the bare infinitive (without 'to').

questions.text: If he hadn't missed the bus, he _____ here by now.
questions.explanation: Mixed Conditional: Past condition (3rd conditional if-clause) with a present result (2nd conditional main clause).

questions.text: I'm not used to _____ on the left side of the road.
questions.explanation: 'Be used to' is followed by a noun or gerund (-ing), meaning 'accustomed to'.

questions.text: The house, _____ was built in 1890, is being renovated.
questions.explanation: Non-defining relative clauses use 'which' for things and require commas.

questions.text: You _____ have paid for the tickets. Entrance was free!
questions.explanation: 'Needn't have' expresses that an action happened but was unnecessary.

questions.text: By the end of next year, they _____ their new house.
questions.explanation: Future Perfect ('will have built') describes an action that will be completed before a specific time in the future.

questions.text: I regret _____ you that your application has been rejected.
questions.explanation: 'Regret to tell' is used to announce bad news formally. 'Regret telling' would mean regretting a past action.

questions.text: Not only _____ late, but he also forgot his wallet.
questions.explanation: Inversion: When starting a sentence with negative adverbials like 'Not only', the subject and auxiliary verb invert.

questions.text: It's time we _____ home.
questions.explanation: 'It's time' is followed by the Past Simple to express that something should be done now.
